title: Will Montenegro's Milo Djukanovic resign, lose a vote of confidence, or cease to be Prime Minister before 1 January 2016?
preds: 11 hours to go so he would have to die. Odds seem to be less than the 0.5% I would require to round up to 1%.
A very Happy New Year to all. May 2016 bring Good Luck to all. SneakyPete
(no change) Glad question is closing before the upcoming vote of confidence in 2016.
No news organizations are talking about anything that could lead up to this, and I suggest that he could hold on for a few days even if things turn bad.
Lowering from 3% to 1% discounting for time
He got the NATO invite and support for NATO membership is growing.

with just 13 days to go til this forecast can be checked, there is no sign that the October protests have carried enough weight to accomplish the goal.  Given that anything is possible, I'll allow a 1% chance of this event.
Why is this even a question?
Recent developments suggest that this is less likely.
Though there is a strong resistance among the population to join NATO, the distribution of power in parliament does not reflect nations positions on this question.
I'm coming to this late - with a huge advantage as a consequence. That scenario is not going to play out in the next fortnight: no!

NATO accession sews this one up for a while, I think. The Russian-backed(?) protests seem minor, and I suspect the country is simply too far away (and surrounded by other NATO countries, for direct Russian action to take place. It would require some quick and odd politics from this point - not impossible, but hardly likely.

- last 25 years 3 y out of office: a priori change 1% a month; 0.5% for remaining period of Dec
- last 9 years 3 y out of office: aprior change of 3,5% a month: 1.7 % for remaining period of Dec

- Invitation for NATO membership in his pocket
- Protests in the Streets asking for his resignation after 25 years

May as well go down from my 1% forecast of 12 November.

-4 Think that there is very little scope for any of the criteria in the question to be satisfied in the time frame.

No change, but here is what NATO has actually done regarding Montenegro:
The attempt at a "color" revolution under the guise of opposition to NATO has failed.  Djukanovic survives to rule another day.
I can't see this changing in the next month. Nothing else has seemed to happen according to the news since the last protests.
Unlikely, particularly if they do join NATO.
Recently protests have remained largely peaceful, there is no referendum for Djukanovic to step down at this time.
Pulling it down to zero. I haven't followed this closely, but nothing makes me think this will happen, and evidently most forecasters agree.
When it comes to Brier scores, I may as well be hanged for a sheep as a lamb.
Not even strongmen can pretend the refugee crisis will not strain their societies to breaking points.

MP Kaludjerovic did indeed ask Djukanovic to resign. Djukanovic, like most politicians, graciously side-stepped the question.
http://www.cdm.me/english/question-time-pm-on-nato-invitation-progress-report-multimillionaires-in-montenegro-privatisations

Djukanovic has no intention of resigning. http://www.balkaninsight.com/en/article/montenegrin-pm-says-he-won-t-resign-10-23-2015  This is his fourth term as Prime Minister - the first from 1991 to 1998.  He's been at the heart of Montenegro politics for a long time, he has weathered criminal investigations and political upheaval and his opponents aren't nearly as organized as Djukanovic's organization.  I really don't see anyone taking him out of power between now and New Year's.

The protests in late OCT of 10,000 people were the high point, numbers now are around 3,000, and mostly older people.  Unless larger mobilization of younger protesters materialize, Milo Djukanovic will remain in power into next year.
The voice of the people won't be ignored
not enough time.  he has lasted throughout a lot of dislike.
Not enough time for this to come to fruition.  Winter in Montenegro can be harsh, so protests will wait until spring 2016.  Besides, Russia is busy in Syria right now.

MP to ask Djukanovic to resign November 18th.
(It appears MP questions must be submitted in advance. Either that, or the author of the article is making it up.)
http://www.cdm.me/english/what-will-mps-ask-djukanovic

.The government has been relatively stable in the last two years, but the Prime Minister's age (and duration in office) have brought out the opposition.  The migration/refugee issue (with the accompanying change in tone after the Paris attacks) will add to the current political environment to drive significant flux.  There are allegations of corruption, although nothing substantiated as of yet.  The legislature is very representative (1 representative for roughly ten thousand citizens), so individual legislators are inherently much more sensitive to the desires of their constituents.  The demonstrations have been (as of yet) relatively small numerically, but as a percentage of the population it has to be taken into account that it is a very small country.
â€‹

Russia's proxy in the fight (Serbs in Montenegro) are nowhere near strong enough to bring about this result in this short of a time frame.  The first round of opposition demonstrations was successfully suppressed and organizing a second round (which could lead to ouster) will take some time.

he seems p crap but it's three in the morning so I'm not translating montenegran news pages plus he probs is corrupting the media like everything else, a bit difficult to tell, need to research political process in montenegro more
Protests in and by themselves are useless, and these ones are not strong enough.
Adjusting downward after looking at Graphs and Stats, miserable conformist that I am.
The crowds are too small (at this point) to drive him out, particularly since he still has significant support.
He is powerful dictator. Have big police force and he is using them in brutal way.
Don't need to be on the wrong side of the consensus on this one right now.

While the prime minister has "allegedly" done a great deal of maleficent deeds, he has done many throughout his time in power and has rarely had to resign. Given the time frame it seems unlikely that the prime minister will step down before the end of the year.

Djukanovic was just praised for making progress on EC benchmarks.  He believes NATO will invite. He still has security forces on his side during protests.  Parliament started to strip anti-NATO voices within.  Djukanovic has stated he would call for early elections after the NATO meeting in December (doubtful). Parliament Speaker Krivokapic steps in to meet with protesters, and as needed, is the spokesperson for government unity.
Low probability event, Montenegro being considered for inclusion in NATO  and local politics not out of control

Montenegro seems like a very stable country, and resigning the PM position is a great way to make your country look suspicious in the eyes of NATO (at least, I'm guessing that's what Djukanovic thinks). Plus, it's probably nice to be the head of a country so long as you aren't in immediate physical peril, which doesn't seem to be the case here. If he didn't resign in the first few days of protest, it seems very unlikely that he will resign as the situation cools off.

Djukanovic has said he wouldn't resign in the face of protests, which don't seem strong enough to oust him at this point. A vote of no confidence would require a majority in parliament. As of now, his party (DPS) and allied parties (SDP, HGI, Bosniak) hold 44 out of 81 seats. Unless there are defectors, he is safe.
The protests and the fact that he switches jobs alot.

Heading south, following @Khalid and thanks @mike97mike for the news link. No need to deviate from the wisdom of the crowd on this one.

Following @Khalid.  I like his style and resources. There is little cause for concern here. He will not resign, nor be driven from office by MPs who fostered violence during the recent protest and themselves facing criminal prosecution.
Increasing due to news that rallies are planned for this Sunday.
I knew practically nothing about Montenegro and Djukanovic before rather unnecessarily jumping into the NATO invitation question, but now that I'm in I may as well attempt this one as well.
Initial forecast - short timeframe, and the demonstrations to date do not seem to be of a level sufficient to cause a change in leadership. Elections are scheduled in any case.

Timescale seems far too short, past precedent lacking, and Djukanovic's power too entrenched and long-term, with no obvious replacement with sufficiently widespread popular support yet evident.  (Protest leaders being relatively second-rank - unlike those who were prominent e.g. before "rose" and "orange" revolutions in Georgia and Ukraine). Not convinced a comparison with pre-2000 Serbia stands either, for several reasons.

I have not found any information to suggest a vote of no confidence is planned or that the ruling parliamentary coalition is breaking up.  Milo Đukanović says he is not resigning.  The crackdown in October was violent but most of the protests and rallies have been peaceful.
Leaving 1% for a NATO invitation ending badly.

From what I understand, the opposition to him is not that overwhelming or united. Initial forecast, perhaps to be revised later.

General elections are in the Spring of 2016, and at least for now the demonstrations in the country have been peaceful. With the elections approaching it is my measured opinion that the demonstrators will wait until the elections to express their desire for a free and democratic state.

With elections coming up early next year and a record of decent elections in the country I don't think it's likely that there will be enough of a groundswell of protest to force a resignation.  Why protest out in the cold in the middle of winter when you'll have an opportunity to go to the polls soon anyway?  Unless you're truly outraged at a leader - and it doesn't sound right now like that's the case for many of Montenegrins - I think you just wait for the election.

Resignation or losing a vote of confidence are both unimaginable options in current timeframe and context. 0% 
2% for coup, assisted on non-assisted by FSB/Serbia, opposition is divided and doesn't look able to arrange anything serious. Power structures seem to be well controlled by government.
2% for everything else, including polonium, umbrellas, little green men, meteorites, etc.

Possible due to protests and instability of region.  Not likely to happen in such a short time frame, especially with elections scheduled for early 2016.
